Message.Title: Dell Seeks Buyout to End Public Scrutiny 25 Years Post-IPO: Tech
Message.Msg: http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-01-15/dell-seeks-buyout-to-end-public-scrutiny-25-years-post-ipo-tech.html?cmpid=yhoo Dell Inc. (DELL)’s buyout talks could finally give founder Michael Dell the chance to jump-start growth after years of half-measures have fallen short. Dell, the third-largest personal-computer maker, is discussing a leveraged buyout with private-equity firms TPG Capital and Silver Lake, a person with knowledge of the matter said yesterday

Message.Title: Coincidence?
Message.Msg: Roughly a week ago, Dell's head of mergers and acquisitions, Dave Johnson, left the company to join the private equity division of Blackstone. Now that might be a coincidence that a week after the head of Dell's mergers group leaves, news outlets begin reporting that Dell might be in talks to be taken private. But I have to admit that that would be the coincidence of the century. A more likely scenario is that Johnson transitioned over to Blackstone to help cement the deal and help bring Dell to the next phase of its growth cycle.

Message.Title: Apple can Easily BUY DELL (with cash)
Message.Msg: with cash Apple has sitting around. But why bother? Dell is losing market share, and little or no growth. Apple would be better off buying its own shares, higher growth and higher profit margins, even if both slow some.

Topic.Title: Apple can Easily BUY DELL (with cash)

Message.Msg: This is why the company is being taken private. For too long the market has refused to value the company appropriate and can only throw stones at it. I have a hard time even understanding why you've made your post here? Is it about Apple or Dell? Your post could be made on the boards of 95% of other stocks in the universe, most notably HP. However, for some reason, with the company carrying massive debt in comparison to Dell, lower earnings, management and business fiascoes for the past decade, and write-downs galore, yet for some reason the market is bidding up the shares. I say more power to Michael and the private equity folks. Make as much money as you can off this. Common folks will complain that this is just another piece of evidence how the deck is stacked against them (how, I don't know). As for Apple, it's heading for it's own cliff - get prepared. It may have tons of cash, but when the growth goes away, you think it's going to get more respect than Dell? APPL will be chopped by $100 billion in value in a matter of weeks. Then, because the company has a lower market cap and comprises a lower proportion of the index, your big index funds will be forced to sell driving it down even more/faster. It works in reverse the same way as when it goes higher.

Message.Title: stock buyback
Message.Msg: Besides making money, DELL has had a robust stock buyback program in place... prev 10k shows: “We also repurchased approximately 178 million shares of common stock for $2.7 billion during Fiscal 2012 . . .” during the third quarter of Fiscal 2012, our Board of Directors authorized an additional $5 billion for our share repurchase program.” If DELL feels strongly enough to be repurchasing about 10% of their shares annually; continuing to be profitable; then why is a buyout so unbelievable? If anything, I say let the bidding war begin. I’ll part with my shares over $20/sh.

Topic.Title: Apple can Easily BUY DELL (with cash)

Message.Msg: aapl makes $$s on hardware only... vs. dell which makes on hardware & services

Topic.Title: what rights do the current shareholders have

Message.Msg: Since Michael holds 15% and large mutual funds and institutions (pension funds) hold the bulk, with individual shareholders owning a small amount in comparison, their vote is next to meaningless. If the majority of the shares voted accept the offer, then it is a done deal for all shareholders at whatever the price agreed to by management is. If you are unhappy with that, you are free to not accept the offer and petition the court (I believe the Delaware Chancery Court) for a binding independent valuation, however, for an individual shareholder, I don't believe it is really feasible or cost effective for the amount you'd stand to gain versus the costs/time involved.

Topic.Title: Dell lost order

Message.Msg: erm, you realise this is talk about a LBO and Dell going private, not aspects of its PC business, which it is moving away from, hence the talks of a LBO so it can re-structure out of the limelight...the question is, will the LBO fail? If it does, then the stock probably will fall back down to arond $9-10 a share...if the LBO happens, and things fall Dell's way, we could see a buy out as high at $18-20 a share, but if it does happen, which seems very likely based on EVIDENCE so far, not just speculation, it will probably settle at $15-16, although this will not make those long and big in Dell happy...but Mr Dell knows the direction his company needs to go, and taking it private at this point makes perfect sense, its just how attached is he to his college dorm room baby...will he let it go at a reasonable price, or will he force the LBO to fail by demanding to high of a buyout...I;m a hold...I don't have a lot of shares, but I got in low in November, so no matter what happens, I won't stand to lose and I'm willing to 'gamble' that the LBO goes trough around $15-16, although if Dell can and the holders with say can mangage a better deal, then cool beans...but if you've just now bought it, I would probably be nervous...but I think its a strong buy, all the signs for the LBO are there...

No. And this is not 2010 Dell hype, this is the real deal...anybody with a small amount of common sense and analytical capabilities can see the writing on the wall...Dell wants to restructure his business, out of the public eye, and is serious as cancer about doing...its just sad we have to put up with day traders and fund managers trying to scare small and medium investors into selling so they can scoop up cheaper shares and make more money when the LBO happen....but I think you're just a sad little man who shorted dell even before the pop hit, now your blagging about CIG on a Dell board...honestly, short day trading investors amaze me...you're so thick get a real job and invest wisely...

Topic.Title: With $9b in Goodwill, Stock holder Equity only $10b, Sell Dell & buy CIG for 2x potential

Message.Msg: Have you noticed that even with over $9 billion in Goodwill, Stock Holder Equity of DELL is only about $10 billion ... When you take company private the Goodwill value becomes almost useless and without that 9 billion in Goodwill DELL Share Holder Equity would be about $1 billion ... how much would you think investment banks be willing to pay for a company with $b billion in share holder Equity ... You could just wait for a few days see how far investment banks would value DELL stock / market-cap ... but if you factor in the probability of that risk you may be better off selling DELL now ... Selling DELL and cashing in the profit and buying CIg with that money seems to be a good thing do .. only if one is keen on making more profit rather than sitting on this current DELL and feel sorry later ... It looks like Michael Dell tried wanted to take DELL private even in 2012 .. again he must be able to convince investment banks that DELL is really worth it ... Again selling DELL and buying CIG might be a good idea NOW / TODAY

Message.Msg: just imho

Message.Title: Delusional
Message.Msg: Even by Yahoo's low standards, it's amazing what is being posted here. The price mentioned by CNBC of $13.5 to $14 sounds about right. Nobody is going to pay $16 for this company. Way too much money. At that price, the projected return would be too low for PE. There will be no OTHER offer. There will be no INCREASE in the offer. This isn't a company in play! It's a distressed company looking to reinvent itself via privatization. Nobody else could possibly buy Dell nor would they want to. Your fantasies of a bidding war are laughable. There will be no increase in the original offer price. If there is a deal, whatever they work out as the price will be the FINAL offer. If it is somehow shot down, they will not increase, and the stock will tank. The huge volume you've seen is ACCUMULATION. Not by speculators. But by those who know about the deal. Why? Because they need to get enough shares into FRIENDLY hands to guarantee they have the votes to close the deal. Get it? The stock should sell off to about $12.50 tomorrow. That is a reasonable discount given the very real risks (deal hits a snag, deal not being accepted by shareholders, TIME/DELAY, etc) and the range of prices mentioned. GLTA.

Topic.Title: Delusional

Message.Msg: "Maybe it pulls back to $12.50 until the bid becomes public, as you say, just because the upside would be limited." Not just the upside being limited. The discount is due to the RISKS. There are many. The deal could hit a snag. The shareholders could reject the deal. The shareholders could sue - delaying any deal for many months. There could be govt issues (Dell is a GLOBAL company). If the price really is $13.50-$14, those who think it'll be an easy payday for a two week wait are just fooling themselves.

Topic.Title: It is looking like typical pump and dump

Message.Msg: Of course it is, who is going to spend $ 22 Billions @ $13/sh or $ 24 Billions @ $14/sh.? there are 1.7 Billion shares, never seen a buyout of a company with so many shares. I really can not believe anybody would spend that kind of money, unless of course Dell is planning is divert the PC business, Monitors, Alienware etc. But looks clear as a usual pump and dump. Eventually it has to be broken up to survive.

Topic.Title: What happens to shares in your account after buyout?

Message.Msg: In a buyout, shares will be sold, taken away and replaced with cash.

Topic.Title: Delusional

Message.Title: shrewd M. Dell move
Message.Msg: taking advantage of low valuation, most investors won't want to wait for it to rebound above 14 and will take quick money

Topic.Title: Delusional

Message.Msg: You got your own dellusions. This is NOT a distressed company. It is a successful company that is simply not the high growth company it once was. The price and dividends now reflect it as a value company. It does not need to reinvent itself through privatization. That just more bs. There is no sense of urgency. This is not GM. The privatization is just a tactic to get these shares into the hands of bankers and key insiders where they can rinse and repeat the IPO game. It would not surpise me if the stock falls tomorrow. It had quite a runup in the past few weeks. But there should be no desperation on shareholders to submit to a final offer. I would regard this as pure market corruption if shareholders are forced to sell their shares at a price dictated by key insiders and investment banks. That should be the real story here.

Topic.Title: Delusional

Message.Msg: 1) The word is "delusion". 2) There is nothing delusional about having a difference of opinion. You don't think ti's distressed. I do. Fine - we can agree to disagree. However, posters dreaming about a bidding war with Samsung and others, or a $20 buyout price, is really a bit nuts - no? 3) Michael Dell disagrees with you. But what does he know. Clearly, you know this company better than he does.

Topic.Title: BUNCH of IDIOTS sold shares AH

Message.Msg: IMO - Concerted effort to bring share price down to where a LBO is seen as shareholder relief... This was planned all along to aquire a "better than gold" hedge against inflation by really smart people, at half price.This stratergy ensures than when the time comes to move on, there is built in equity. Whether the "Deal" gets done or not, Dell is still a very attractive buy even at the $18 level where I belive this deal gets closed, short term. If deal does not happen, Dell is a long term $25 a share candidate. I am long and buying on dips.

Message.Title: 25bn is chump change
Message.Msg: SAMSUNG may counter, heard it on this board, someone mentioned it but the idea does have a lot of merit and the logic seems solid and watertight. think about it, they can get into the ENTIRE US CORPORATE space for a mere 25bn, nothing for them, a drop in the bucket. funny how cnbc says 20bn is "too much" bla bla bla, what are we a poor 3rd world country?!??!??!?! 25bn is NOTHING its CHUMP CHANGE!!!!!!!!! agrrrrr!!!!!! tight stops folks and be good ;_)
